questions.question: Which traditional Scottish instrument, known for its droning sound, is iconic in massed band performances?
questions.hint: Massed ranks of this wind instrument are a famous sight and sound at military parades.

questions.question: Which conflict was referred to as "the war to end all wars"?
questions.hint: It was a hopeful label given to the Great War due to its unprecedented carnage.

questions.question: Who was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize?
questions.hint: She won in 1903 for her work on radiation, sharing the honor with her husband and Henri Becquerel.

questions.question: In what year did the Berlin Wall fall, symbolizing the end of the Cold War divide in Europe?
questions.hint: It happened on November 9 of that year, amid a wave of revolutions in Eastern Europe.

questions.question: Who served as the first Prime Minister of Australia?
questions.hint: He took office at the Federation of Australia on January 1, 1901.

questions.question: Who was the first woman to serve as Prime Minister of Australia?
questions.hint: She took office in 2010 as Australia's 27th Prime Minister.

questions.question: Which country has the longest total coastline in the world?
questions.hint: This country has a vast Arctic archipelago, giving it over 200,000 km of coast.

questions.question: Which is the world's largest desert by area?
questions.hint: This desert is cold and ice-covered, nearly twice the size of the Sahara.

questions.question: What is the southernmost national capital city in the world?
questions.hint: This city in New Zealand lies at latitude about 41° South.

questions.question: What is the capital city of Canada?
questions.hint: This city in Ontario was chosen by Queen Victoria as the capital in 1857.

questions.question: Which Australian state is the largest by area?
questions.hint: It covers roughly one-third of the Australian continent.

questions.question: What is the highest mountain in Australia (mainland)?
questions.hint: This peak in New South Wales reaches 2,228 meters above sea level.

questions.question: Which country spans the most time zones (including overseas territories)?
questions.hint: Thanks to its many overseas territories, a European country holds this record (12 time zones).

questions.question: What is the only mammal capable of true flight?
questions.hint: No, it's not a bird – this flying creature is nocturnal and uses echolocation.

questions.question: What is considered the world's most venomous snake by toxicity of venom?
questions.hint: This shy Australian snake's drop-for-drop venom can kill 100 men, earning it the title 'fierce snake'.

questions.question: Which animal is the fastest in the world, able to reach dive speeds over 300 km/h?
questions.hint: This bird of prey swoops down on its targets at astonishing speeds, far faster than any land animal.

questions.question: What is the largest species of shark (and also the largest fish) in the world?
questions.hint: This gentle giant of the ocean is a filter-feeder that can grow over 60 feet long.

questions.question: What is the brightest star in the night sky as seen from Earth (excluding the sun)?
questions.hint: Known as the Dog Star, it's a blazing star in the constellation Canis Major.

questions.question: Which planet is often called the 'Morning Star' or 'Evening Star' due to its brightness?
questions.hint: It's the second planet from the Sun and shines brightly near sunrise or sunset.

questions.question: Which famous composer continued to write music, including his Ninth Symphony, even after becoming completely deaf?
questions.hint: He composed 'Ode to Joy' in his final symphony without being able to hear the notes.

questions.question: Shylock, the Jewish moneylender character, appears in which Shakespeare play?
questions.hint: This play's title refers to a city in Italy, and Shylock demands a 'pound of flesh' as repayment.

questions.question: Which Australian poet wrote the ballads "Waltzing Matilda" and "The Man from Snowy River"?
questions.hint: He was a bush poet whose real first names were Andrew Barton.

questions.question: Which famous artist cut off part of his own ear in 1888 during a fit of mental distress?
questions.hint: This Dutch Post-Impressionist later painted a self-portrait with a bandaged ear.

questions.question: The landscapes of which country were famously used to film the "Lord of the Rings" trilogy?
questions.hint: This island nation in the southern hemisphere provided Middle-earth's scenery, from Hobbiton to Mordor.

questions.question: Who invented the World Wide Web (WWW) in 1989 while working at CERN?
questions.hint: He's an English computer scientist who proposed the web to help scientists share information.

questions.question: Which is the only country that is also a continent?
questions.hint: It's the smallest continent and is a single nation, often called the 'island continent.'

questions.question: Which animal appears alongside the kangaroo on the Australian coat of arms?
questions.hint: This large flightless bird, native to Australia, was chosen because it cannot easily walk backward.

questions.question: The term 'military tattoo' originates from a phrase in which language and what does it mean?
questions.hint: It comes from a 17th-century phrase telling innkeepers to stop serving beer to soldiers.
